and Babel are powerful tools in their own right. Combined with Rollup, they become even more powerful.To provide a seamless experience, Rollup always take precedence when conflicts arise. As a natural consequence of this, some options provided to TypeScript and Babel will be ignored or overridden.</p><div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h3 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">Ignored/overridden TypeScript options</h3><a id="user-content-ignoredoverridden-typescript-options" class="anchor" aria-label="Permalink: Ignored/overridden TypeScript options" href="#ignoredoverridden-typescript-options"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div><p dir="auto">The following <a href="https://www.typescriptlang.org/docs/handbook/compiler-options.html" rel="nofollow">CompilerOptions</a> from a <code>tsconfig</code> will be ignored:</p><table><thead><tr><th>Property</th><th>Reason</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td><code>outDir</code></td><td>Rollup, not TypeScript, will decide where to emit chunks.</td></tr><tr><td><code>module</code></td><td>Rollup, not TypeScript, is the decider of which module system(s) to target based on your Rollup configuration.</td></tr><tr><td><code>outFile</code></td><td>This option produces flat output and only works with the module formats AMD and SystemJS. Rollup will be the decider of how to split code.</td></tr><tr><td><code>sourceMap</code></td><td>TypeScript will always be instructed to produce SourceMaps. Rollup then decides whether or not to include them (and if they should be inlined).</td></tr><tr><td><code>inlineSourceMap</code></td><td>TypeScript will always be instructed to produce SourceMaps. Rollup then decides whether or not to include them (and if they should be inlined).</td></tr><tr><td><code>inlineSources</code></td><td>Since <code>inlineSourceMap</code> is ignored, this option won't take effect.</td></tr><tr><td><code>importHelpers</code></td><td>Helpers will always be imported. This makes it possible for Rollup to code-split properly and share TypeScript helpers across chunks.</td></tr><tr><td><code>moduleResolution</code></td><td>Node-module resolution will always be used. This is required for <code>importHelpers</code> to work and in general, to make TypeScript able to resolve external libraries. Note that you still need to add the <a href="https://github.com/rollup/rollup-plugin-node-resolve">nodeResolve</a> plugin in order to include external libraries within your bundle unless <code>allowJs</code> is <code>true</code> within your <code>tsconfig</code></td></tr><tr><td><code>noEmit</code></td><td>TypeScript should always be able to emit assets, but those will be delegated to Rollup.</td></tr><tr><td><code>noEmitOnError</code></td><td>See above.</td></tr><tr><td><code>emitDeclarationOnly</code></td><td>See above.</td></tr><tr><td><code>noEmitHelpers</code></td><td>TypeScript should always be able to emit helpers, since the <code>importHelpers</code> option is forced</td></tr><tr><td><code>noResolve</code></td><td>TypeScript should always be able to resolve things. Otherwise, compilation might break.</td></tr><tr><td><code>watch</code></td><td>Rollup, not TypeScript, will watch files if run in watch mode. Efficient caching will still be used for optimum performance.</td></tr><tr><td><code>preserveWatchOutput</code></td><td>See above</td></tr></tbody></table><p dir="auto">The following additional options will also be ignored:</p><table><thead><tr><th>Property</th><th>Reason</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td><code>include</code></td><td>Rollup itself will decide which files to include in the transformation process based on your code. This plugin itself takes a <code>include</code> property which you should use instead if you want to explicitly allow specific files or globs.</td></tr><tr><td><code>exclude</code></td><td>See above.</td></tr></tbody></table><div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h4 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">Behavior of esModuleInterop</h4><a id="user-content-behavior-of-esmoduleinterop" class="anchor" aria-label="Permalink: Behavior of esModuleInterop" href="#behavior-of-esmoduleinterop"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div><p dir="auto">Given that Rollup, not TypeScript, is the decider of which module system(s) to target based on your Rollup configuration, TypeScript will always emit ES modules that Rollup can understand and work with.</p><p dir="auto">The <code>esModuleInterop</code> option to TypeScript is respected, but its emit-characteristics won't have an impact on your bundle. Instead, you may consult <a href="https://rollupjs.org/guide/en/#outputinterop" rel="nofollow">the Rollup documentation for the <code>interop</code> option</a> to achievethe same thing with Rollup.</p><div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h3 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">Ignored/overridden Babel options</h3><a id="user-content-ignoredoverridden-babel-options" class="anchor" aria-label="Permalink: Ignored/overridden Babel options" href="#ignoredoverridden-babel-options"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div><p dir="auto">The following <a href="https://babeljs.io/docs/en/options" rel="nofollow">Babel options</a> will be ignored:</p><table><thead><tr><th>Property</th><th>Reason</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td><code>sourceMaps</code></td><td>Babel will always be instructed to produce SourceMaps. Rollup then decides whether or not to include them (and if they should be inlined).</td></tr><tr><td><code>cwd</code></td><td>The <code>cwd</code> option provided to the plugin will always be used.</td></tr><tr><td><code>include</code></td><td>Rollup itself will decide which files to include in the transformation process based on your code. This plugin itself takes a <code>include</code> property which you should use instead if you want to explicitly allow specific files or globs.</td></tr><tr><td><code>exclude</code></td><td>See above</td></tr><tr><td><code>ignore</code></td><td>See above</td></tr><tr><td><code>only</code></td><td>See above</td></tr><tr><td><code>sourceType</code></td><td>Will always use <code>module</code>. Rollup will then decide what to do based on the output format</td></tr></tbody></table><div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h3 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">Ignored/overridden swc options</h3><a id="user-content-ignoredoverridden-swc-options" class="anchor" aria-label="Permalink: Ignored/overridden swc options" href="#ignoredoverridden-swc-options"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div><p dir="auto">The following <a href="https://swc.rs/docs/configuration/swcrc" rel="nofollow">Babel options</a> will be ignored:</p><table><thead><tr><th>Property</th><th>Reason</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td><code>sourceMaps</code></td><td>swc will always be instructed to produce SourceMaps. Rollup then decides whether or not to include them (and if they should be inlined).</td></tr><tr><td><code>cwd</code></td><td>The <code>cwd</code> option provided to the plugin will always be used.</td></tr><tr><td><code>cwd</code></td><td>See above.</td></tr><tr><td><code>test</code></td><td>Rollup itself will decide which files to include in the transformation process based on your code. This plugin itself takes a <code>include</code> property which you should use instead if you want to explicitly allow specific files or globs.</td></tr><tr><td><code>exclude</code></td><td>See above</td></tr><tr><td><code>isModule</code></td><td>Will always use <code>true</code>. Rollup will then decide what to do based on the output format</td></tr></tbody></table><div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h3 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">Default Babel plugins</h3><a id="user-content-default-babel-plugins" class="anchor" aria-label="Permalink: Default Babel plugins" href="#default-babel-plugins"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div><p dir="auto">If you decide to use Babel as the transpiler with the <code>transpiler</code> plugin option set to <code>"babel"</code>, some best-practice default plugins and presets will be applied such that you don't have to configure anything on your own.By default, the plugin will conditionally apply the <code>@babel/preset-env</code> preset if a Browserslist is provided or located, as well as plugins for handling <a href="https://babeljs.io/docs/en/babel-preset-env#shippedproposals" rel="nofollow">shipped proposals</a>. And, the <code>@babel/plugin-runtime</code> plugin will be used for extracting Babel helpers and reusing them across your chunks to avoid code duplication.</p><p dir="auto">If you provide these presets or plugins yourself through the found or provided Babel config, <em>your</em> config options will take precedence.</p><p dir="auto">Here's table with a full overview of the specifics:</p><table><thead><tr><th>Preset/Plugin</th><th>Condition</th><th>Reason</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td><code>@babel/preset-env</code></td><td>A Browserslist is provided or found automatically, and you don't provide this preset yourself within your Babel config</td><td>This preset enables you to base your syntax transformations on the specific browsers/environment you want your application or library to target. It will "<em>Just Work"</em></td></tr><tr><td><code>@babel/preset-typescript</code></td><td>Babel is being used for transforming TypeScript-specific syntax.</td><td>This preset enables you to transform TypeScript-specific syntax. If you declare this in your own babel config, your configuration options will still be respected.</td></tr><tr><td><code>@babel/plugin-transform-runtime</code></td><td>You don't provide this plugin yourself within your Babel config</td><td>Depending on your configuration, async functions may be rewritten to use <a href="https://github.com/facebook/regenerator/tree/master/packages/regenerator-runtime">Regenerator Runtime</a>, and there may be one or more Babel helpers injected within your code. <code>@babel/plugin-runtime</code> allows this plugin to avoid duplicating these helpers, and instead make them shared across Chunks seamlessly via Rollup.</td></tr></tbody></table><div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h2 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">Contributing</h2><a id="user-content-contributing" class="anchor" aria-label="Permalink: Contributing" href="#contributing"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div><p dir="auto">Do you want to contribute? dir="auto">Does this plugin work with Code Splitting?</h4><a id="user-content-does-this-plugin-work-with-code-splitting" class="anchor" aria-label="Permalink: Does this plugin work with Code Splitting?" href="#does-this-plugin-work-with-code-splitting"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div><p dir="auto">Absolutely, even with Declaration files. Things will work seamlessly.</p><div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h4 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">Why wouldn't you use just TypeScript?</h4><a id="user-content-why-wouldnt-you-use-just-typescript" class="anchor" aria-label="Permalink: Why wouldn't you use just TypeScript?" href="#why-wouldnt-you-use-just-typescript"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div><p dir="auto">The TypeScript compiler, while extremely powerful, has the restriction that it can only target a specific ECMAScript version.In reality, browsers and other ECMAScript environments has varying support for newer language features.Some browsers support even those features that haven't been publicized yet, while others support only parts of the latest language features.</p><p dir="auto">In effect, a browser may support a lot of modern features such as classes and proper lexical scoping, but lack others.With TypeScript, it's <em>"all-or-nothing"</em>: If you want to support a Browser with partial support, you must target the latest publicized ECMAScript version that the browser fully supports.</p><p dir="auto">Babel, on the other hand, is far more granular in its design and applies syntax transformations on a feature-by-feature basis.Combined with something like <code>@babel/preset-env</code>, individual transformations can be applied for only those language features that are missing.This means that you can use things like classes and lexical scoping in browsers that otherwise doesn't fully support all of the ES2015 specification.</p><div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h4 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">Okay, then why wouldn't you use just babel?</h4><a id="user-content-okay-then-why-wouldnt-you-use-just-babel" class="anchor" aria-label="Permalink: Okay, then why wouldn't you use just babel?" href="#okay-then-why-wouldnt-you-use-just-babel"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div><p dir="auto">Babel has support for <a href="https://babeljs.io/docs/en/babel-plugin-transform-typescript" rel="nofollow">parsing and transforming TypeScript</a>. While Babel can be used for everything, there are some caveats:</p><p dir="auto">The Babel compiler works on a file-by-file basis, meaning it is simple to use and reason about, whereas the TypeScript compiler works with <em>Programs</em>, or in other words sets of related <em>SourceFiles</em>.This gives TypeScript the advantage over Babel that it has a greater understanding of your codebase in general and can understand your types across files.</p><div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h4 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">When combined with Babel, what does TypeScript do, and what does Babel do?</h4><a id="user-content-when-combined-with-babel-what-does-typescript-do-and-what-does-babel-do" class="anchor" aria-label="Permalink: When combined with Babel, what does TypeScript do, and what does Babel do?" href="#when-combined-with-babel-what-does-typescript-do-and-what-does-babel-do"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div><p dir="auto">When you use Babel as a transpiler in its default configuration, the TypeScript Compiler will have the responsibility of:</p><ul dir="auto"><li>Emitting TypeScript diagnostics</li><li>Emitting TypeScript declaration (<code>.d.ts</code>) files and TypeScript declaration map (<code>.d.ts.map</code>) files.</li></ul><p dir="auto">Babel will then purely perform syntax transformations based on your configuration.</p><p dir="auto">You can also opt in to using the TypeScript compiler to remove TypeScript specific syntax from your code when combined with babel. This grants you the power to combine the strengths of the TypeScript compiler,which understands the structure of your codebase, with the flexibility and plugin ecosystem of Babel.</p><p dir="auto">Please read <a href="#mixing-transpilers">this section</a> for details on how you can mix transpilers to achieve that. In such a setup, TypeScript is also responsible for:</p><ul dir="auto"><li>Removing TypeScript-specific features such as types, type-only imports, enums, and TypeScript decorators.</li><li>Other TypeScript features that may require understanding the relationship between your files.</li></ul><p dir="auto">Babel will then be used for all other syntax transformation from then on, depending on the combination of default, provided, and forced presets and plugins.</p><div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h4 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">When combined with swc, what does TypeScript do, and what does Babel do?</h4><a id="user-content-when-combined-with-swc-what-does-typescript-do-and-what-does-babel-do" class="anchor" aria-label="Permalink: When combined with swc, what does TypeScript do, and what does Babel do?" href="#when-combined-with-swc-what-does-typescript-do-and-what-does-babel-do"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1"
